trans-unit.source: N
trans-unit.note: An abbreviation of the direction North

trans-unit.source: Maze
trans-unit.note: brief title - Specifies that this is Blockly's '''Maze''' tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Which direction am I facing after this program ends?
trans-unit.note: instructions - program' refers to a series of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.

trans-unit.source: no path to the right
trans-unit.note: condensed form of 'if there is a no path to the right', as in: 'if no path to the right, turn right'.

trans-unit.source: pen up
Could you use fewer blocks? Try defining your own function and using it inside one of the loop blocks.
else
trans-unit.note: conjunction - 'otherwise', introducing commands to be performed if a previous condition was not true, as in 'if x>3, do this, else do that'.

trans-unit.source: height
Create a new function that removes 3 shovelfuls from a pile, and use it to help me level out all the piles.
pen down
Here is an 'if-else' block: I move forward if there is a path ahead, otherwise I turn left.
trans-unit.note: instructions - An example of an 'if-else' block is if there is a path ahead move forward, else turn left.

trans-unit.source: Using "draw a square" as an example, add an input named "length" to "draw a triangle". Then, draw triangles in different colors around the animals.
This level can be solved with %1 blocks. You used %2.
Reach the goal using only five blocks.
trans-unit.note: instructions - the goal is reaching the end point in a maze; 'block' refers to a child's building block.

trans-unit.source: Add a "height" input to "draw a house" and build a big house for the elephant.
It's nighttime, and I can't tell how large the piles are. Now I don't have all the options I used to have on the while block. Move me along the field, and if there is a pile, remove it.
A small change to the blocks from the previous maze will solve this level.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'blocks' refers to a child's building blocks

trans-unit.source: You could solve this level with fewer blocks. Can you find a solution with fewer blocks?
trans-unit.note: hint - 'block' refers to a child's stackable toys.

trans-unit.source: put down tower
trans-unit.note: Place a tower on the ground

trans-unit.source: Congratulations! You have completed this level.
trans-unit.note: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the maze, inviting them to precede to the next level of difficulty.

trans-unit.source: Find the familiar blocks in the new categories to draw a square in your favorite color.
You're now free to do whatever you want. One idea is to try running this program with different turn amounts (higher or lower than 90). Other ideas are to draw a star, circle, heart, or animal.
Help me flatten the field on my farm so it's ready for planting. Move me to the pile of dirt to remove it.
Show me
Moves the turtle forward or backward by the specified amount.
Use the function block to make me fill in all the holes.
Make me fill in all the holes. Each hole needs 5 shovelfuls of dirt.
There's a cow in my field! Write a new function that helps me avoid the cow and remove the pile.
Draw a triangle whose sides are all 100 dots and are in random colors. You'll have to figure out how far to turn.
heading
trans-unit.note: block text - the compass direction toward which a traveler or vehicle is or should be moving; course.

trans-unit.source: Use the 'if-else' block to help me get out of the maze!
trans-unit.note: instructions - an example of an 'if-else' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left, else or otherwise turn right'.

trans-unit.source: I'm a turtle with chalk on my belly. Stack up blocks and press "Run Program" to make me draw the shown picture.
path to the left
trans-unit.note: condensed form of 'if there is a path to the left', as in: 'if path to the left, turn left'.

trans-unit.source: text
trans-unit.note: variable name - Default [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/Variables variable] representing a [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/Text piece of text]. This should be a single word, preferably short.

trans-unit.source: No - Try tracking my direction while following the program.
trans-unit.note: tracking is suggesting to the user that they should follow each instruction and follow how that will affect the movement. A 'program' is a set of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.

trans-unit.source: fill 1
trans-unit.note: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person putting down a ball.

trans-unit.source: Can you use the while block to complete the level with only 4 blocks?
trans-unit.note: hint - A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over. The red marker is the goal to be reached in the maze.

trans-unit.source: I don't know how many shovelfuls of dirt this hole needs. Write a program that makes me fill it until it's even.
This level can be solved with %1 blocks.
trans-unit.note: alert - This is displayed when the user has used more blocks than is necessary.

trans-unit.source: pickup tower
trans-unit.note: Place a tower up off the ground

trans-unit.source: degrees
Run Program
trans-unit.note: button label - Pressing the button runs the computer program the user has written.

trans-unit.source: Makes the player do what the blocks say.
trans-unit.note: tooltip - Pressing this button runs the computer program the user has written to move the player through the level.

trans-unit.source: Lifts or lowers the pen, to start or stop drawing.
put down 5
move forward by
while
trans-unit.note: verb - imperative or infinitive to repeat the following commands. The phrase is followed by the symbol denoting the end of the maze.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations! You have solved the final level.
trans-unit.note: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the most difficult level.

trans-unit.source: hide turtle
Repeat the enclosed actions until finish point is reached.
trans-unit.note: tooltip (pop-up help) - Repeat the enclosed commands until the maze has been successfully completed (the end point reached).

trans-unit.source: I will have to turn left when I cannot go straight. Use an 'if' block to see if their is a path in another direction.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'turn left' refers to rotating in place a quarter circle counter-clockwise. An example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.

trans-unit.source: Modify this program with the "counter" block (found in the Variables category) to draw the same series of squares with fewer blocks than on the previous level.
repeat until finish
trans-unit.note: verb - imperative or infinitive to repeat the following commands. The phrase is followed by the symbol denoting the end of the maze.

trans-unit.source: Changes the width of the pen.
Continue
trans-unit.note: button - Closes the dialog and continues to the next level

trans-unit.source: Can you find a solution using 2 blocks? Try using the given function(s).
Make me fill in the hole at the end of the field, using as few blocks as possible.
Reach the goal using only five blocks.
trans-unit.note: instructions - the goal is reaching the end point in a maze; 'block' refers to a child's building block.

trans-unit.source: This level can be solved with blocks.
trans-unit.note: alert - This is displayed when the user has used more blocks than is necessary.

trans-unit.source: Can you find a solution using 4 blocks? Try putting a loop inside of another loop. Remember, loop blocks are green.
trans-unit.note: hint - A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over.

trans-unit.source: path to the right
trans-unit.note: condensed form of 'if there is a path to the right', as in: 'if path to the right, turn right'.

trans-unit.source: Help
trans-unit.note: The label on a button the user can press for help.\n{lb}{lb}Identical|Help{rb}{rb}

trans-unit.source: Logic
CS First: Turtle Graphics %1
You have 1 block left.
trans-unit.note: warning - Only one more block may be added. Do not alter the portions between pointy brackets (< and >), although you may move them within the phrase and replace 1 with one or more words.

trans-unit.source: You need to use at least %1 different colors on this level. You used only %2.
Color
That's right! Good job.
trans-unit.note: Congratulating the user on correctly answering the question.

trans-unit.source: Move in the direction of the given angle: 0 is to the right, 90 is straight up, etc.
trans-unit.note: tooltip - Move in the direction of the given angle, where 0 means going horizontally to the right, and 90 straight up and 270 straight down.

trans-unit.source: No - Try tracking my direction while following the program.
trans-unit.note: tracking is suggesting to the user that they should follow each instruction and follow how that will affect the movement. A 'program' is a set of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.

trans-unit.source: A program is a sequence of statements. Stack a couple of 'move forward' blocks together to help me reach the goal.
trans-unit.note: instructions - the word 'program' refers to a computer program, and the words for 'stack' and 'blocks' should be the same as for stacking children's blocks. Use the imperative verb form appropriate for speaking to a child, gender unspecified. If no gender-neutral singular/familiar form exists but a gender-neutral plural/formal form exists, use that instead.

trans-unit.source: If-else blocks will do one thing or the other.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'block' refers to a child's building block.

trans-unit.source: You have0 blocks left.
trans-unit.note: warning - No more blocks may be added until some are removed. Do not alter the portions between pointy brackets (< and >), although you may move them within the phrase and replace 0 with one or more words.

trans-unit.source: You are using all of the necessary types of blocks, but try using more of these types of blocks to complete this level.
trans-unit.note: alert - The user has not completed the level, is using all of the necessary types of blocks, but needs more of these types of blocks to complete the level.

trans-unit.source: What should I do to follow the path?
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'steps' refers to instructions in a computer program; 'path' refers to the path through a maze. See previous description for tense.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations! You have solved the final level.
trans-unit.note: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the most difficult level.

trans-unit.source: Reset
trans-unit.note: button label - Pressing the button causes Pegman return to the start of the maze (but does not delete the user's program.)

trans-unit.source: See generated JavaScript code.
if path to the left
trans-unit.note: condensed form of 'if there is a path to the left', as in: 'if path to the left, turn left'.

trans-unit.source: Save and link to blocks.
trans-unit.note: tooltip (pop-up help) for button; pressing the button causes the user's program to be saved and for a URL to be provided for retrieving it. The word 'blocks' is as in children's toy blocks.

trans-unit.source: Can you find a solution by adding 8 blocks in the "avoid the cow and remove 1" block?
do
trans-unit.note: block text - Imperative or infinitive of a verb preceding one or more commands to a person. This is part of [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/Loops#repeat repeat] and [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/IfElse#If_blocks if] blocks.

trans-unit.source: You are using all of the necessary types of blocks but not in the right way.
Try to reach the end of this path using only three blocks.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.

trans-unit.source: W
trans-unit.note: An abbreviation of the direction West

trans-unit.source: Text
trans-unit.note: category - Blocks related to [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/Text text processing].

trans-unit.source: Sorry, '%1' doesn't correspond with any saved program.
trans-unit.note: alert - A request to retrieve a stored program does not have a valid URL. %1 is the invalid portion of the URL.

trans-unit.source: Reset
Try to reach the end of this path using only two repeat blocks.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.

trans-unit.source: Now create a "draw a house" function and use it house two cats.
Can you find a solution using 4 blocks? Try including an if block.
trans-unit.note: hint - A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations! Are you ready to proceed to level %1?
trans-unit.note: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the level, inviting them to precede to the next level of difficulty. %1 is an integer greater than 1.

trans-unit.source: Loops
Turns me left or right by 90 degrees.
trans-unit.note: tooltip (pop-up help) - Pegman is the humanoid icon used in Google Maps. See picture at http://goo.gl/9I64i (http://maps.google.com/intl/en/help/maps/streetview/learn/pegman.html). The term 'space' refers to a single square within a maze.

trans-unit.source: An 'if' condition will do something only if the condition is true. Try turning left if there is a path to the left.
trans-unit.note: instructions - an example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.

trans-unit.source: If there is a path in the specified direction, then do the first block of actions. Otherwise, do the second block of actions.
trans-unit.note: tooltip (pop-up help) - 'path' refers to a path through a maze.

trans-unit.source: S
trans-unit.note: An abbreviation of the direction North

trans-unit.source: Try using the blocks to help me remove all the piles and fill in all the holes on the ground.
Draw whatever you want. One idea is experimenting with different types of spirals. What happens if you change the turn amount, rather than the move amount? TODO: Add starting blocks.
turn right
trans-unit.note: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person turning his head and body one quarter rotation clockwise. Prefer a translation that has text in common with the translation of 'turn left'. See [[Translating:Blockly#Drop-Down_Menus]].

trans-unit.source: No - Try tracking my direction while following the program.
trans-unit.note: tracking is suggesting to the user that they should follow each instruction and follow how that will affect the movement. A 'program' is a set of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.

trans-unit.source: Computers have limited memory. Reach the end of this path using only two blocks.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.

trans-unit.source: That's right!
trans-unit.note: Congratulating the user on correctly answering the question.

trans-unit.source: An 'if' condition will do something only if the condition is true. Try turning right if there is a path to the right.
trans-unit.note: instructions - an example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.

trans-unit.source: draw a square
W
trans-unit.note: An abbreviation of the direction West

trans-unit.source: do
trans-unit.note: verb - imperative or infinitive preceding one or more commands to a person.

trans-unit.source: You can now see how the "draw a square" and "draw a circle" functions are defined. Defining a function doesn't run its blocks. You have to pull out the "draw a square" block to actually draw a square.
See generated JavaScript code.
trans-unit.note: tooltip (pop-up help) for button; pressing the button causes a program in the JavaScript computer language to be displayed, based on the program created by the user.

trans-unit.source: No - Try tracking my direction while following the program.
trans-unit.note: tracking is suggesting to the user that they should follow each instruction and follow how that will affect the movement. A 'program' is a set of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.

trans-unit.source: Can you figure out how draw this triangle and square?
Variables
if path ahead
trans-unit.note: condensed form of 'if there is a path ahead', as in: 'if path ahead, go forward'.

trans-unit.source: See if you can draw these green glasses.
while
trans-unit.note: condensed form of 'while something is true'

trans-unit.source: Moves the turtle forward.
draw a snowman
Reach the goal using only five blocks.
trans-unit.note: instructions - the goal is reaching the end point in a maze; 'block' refers to a child's building block.

trans-unit.source: Turtle 1
trans-unit.note: brief title - Specifies that this is Blockly's '''Turtle 1''' tutorial.

trans-unit.source: no path to the left
trans-unit.note: condensed form of 'if there is a no path to the left', as in: 'if no path to the left, turn left'.

trans-unit.source: Can you find a solution using 6 blocks? Try including 2 if blocks.
trans-unit.note: hint - A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over.

trans-unit.source: Use the function, "avoid the cow and remove 1", to help me remove all the piles.
Turns the turtle right by the specified angle.
Repeat the enclosed actions until finish point is reached.
trans-unit.note: tooltip (pop-up help) - Repeat the enclosed commands until the maze has been successfully completed (the end point reached).

trans-unit.source: Try again
trans-unit.note: button - Closes the dialog and stays on the current level

trans-unit.source: Try to reach the end of this path using only two repeat blocks.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.

trans-unit.source: That's right!
trans-unit.note: Congratulating the user on correctly answering the question.

trans-unit.source: I will have to turn right when I cannot go straight. Use an 'if' block to see if their is a path in another direction.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'turn left' refers to rotating in place a quarter circle counter-clockwise. An example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.

trans-unit.source: Use a "count with" loop to draw a family of snowmen with heights of 110, 100, 90, 80, and 70 dots, each 60 dots apart.
Changes the color of the pen.
path is blocked
trans-unit.note: condensed form of 'if there is a no path ahead', as in: 'if no path ahead, go forward'.

trans-unit.source: There is a solution using only 3 blocks. Can you find it? Did you try the new option on the while block?
trans-unit.note: hint - A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over. The red marker is the goal to be reached in the maze.

trans-unit.source: OK
trans-unit.note: Label on button for user to press when done reading help information.\n{lb}{lb}Identical|OK{rb}{rb}

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.note: No indicates that this option is false and incorrect.

trans-unit.source: Use a "count with" block and your code from the previous level to draw houses of size 50, 100, and 150 in different colors.
Continue
trans-unit.note: button - Closes the dialog and continues to the next level

trans-unit.source: That's right!
trans-unit.note: Congratulating the user on correctly answering the question.

trans-unit.source: there is a pile
trans-unit.note: Indicates the presence of at least one ball, as in 'he brought a ball, there are now balls present'

trans-unit.source: On this level, you need to stack together all of the blocks in the white workspace.
trans-unit.note: alert - This is displayed if a user attempts to run a program composed of multiple stacks of blocks, letting them know they need to create a single stack.

trans-unit.source: A program is a sequence of statements. Stack a couple of 'move forward' blocks together to help me reach the goal.
trans-unit.note: instructions - the word 'program' refers to a computer program, and the words for 'stack' and 'blocks' should be the same as for stacking children's blocks. Use the imperative verb form appropriate for speaking to a child, gender unspecified. If no gender-neutral singular/familiar form exists but a gender-neutral plural/formal form exists, use that instead.

trans-unit.source: Replace the pale (disabled) blocks with a "count with" block (in the Loops category) and "counter" block (in the Variables category) to draw the same spiral.
move forward
trans-unit.note: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person moving (walking) in the direction he/she is facing.

trans-unit.source: Functions
Use the new "draw a square" block, found in the "Functions" category, to draw a small green square.
move backward by
Run
trans-unit.note: button label - Pressing the button runs the computer program the user has written.

trans-unit.source: You got it right!
trans-unit.note: Congratulating the user on correctly answering the question.

trans-unit.source: Remove empty blocks.
trans-unit.note: alert - This error message is displayed when the user has added blocks with nothing nested inside them (e.g. repeat or if blocks).

trans-unit.source: Can you find a solution using 3 blocks? Try using the given function(s) inside a while block.
It's still dark outside. Move me along the field. If there is a pile, remove it, and if there is a hole, fill it in.
Use the new function, "remove 1 and avoid the cow", to make me level out the piles.
Define a new function that removes 7 shovelfuls. Then use it to write a program that helps me remove all the piles.
jump backward by
hungry
trans-unit.note: block text - Experiencing a desire or need for food.

trans-unit.source: Loops
Use the "repeat" block to draw 3 squares of size 100, each 120 degrees apart, in random colors.
Can you find a solution using only 4 blocks? Try using one of the green loop blocks.
Remember:'repeat' blocks perform an action multiple times without additional blocks.'if' blocks check if there is a path in a certain direction.
trans-unit.note: instructions - A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over.

trans-unit.source: Bird
trans-unit.note: title - Specifies that this is Blockly's '''Bird''' tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.note: Yes indicates that this option is true and correct.

trans-unit.source: Using the "draw a square" function as an example, create a "draw a triangle" function and use it.
There is a solution using only 3 blocks. Can you find it? Did you using the repeat block?
trans-unit.note: hint - A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over.

trans-unit.source: Try again
trans-unit.note: button - Closes the dialog and stays on the current level

trans-unit.source: Move me to the pile of dirt and tell me how many shovelfuls to remove using as few blocks as possible.
If-else blocks will do one thing or the other.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'block' refers to a child's building block.

trans-unit.source: Draw squares with sides of 50, 60, 70, 80, and 90 dots. You'll need lots of blocks.
Put the player back at the start of the level.
trans-unit.note: tooltip - Pressing this button restores the player to the start position and enables the user's program to be run again.

trans-unit.source: path ahead
trans-unit.note: condensed form of 'if there is a path ahead', as in: 'if path ahead, go forward'.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations! You have solved the final level.
trans-unit.note: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the most difficult level.

trans-unit.source: there is a hole
trans-unit.note: Indicates the lack of any balls, as in 'she took the last ball, there are now no balls present'

trans-unit.source: If there is a path in the specified direction, then do some actions.
trans-unit.note: tooltip (pop-up help) - 'path' refers to a path through a maze.

repeat until

trans-unit.note: Conditional statement, which evaluates to true or false.

Move me forward one space.

Save and link to blocks.

trans-unit.source: On this level, you need to stack together all of the blocks in the white workspace.

Draw triangular fences around the cats and a square fence around the cow. Tip: Test the program as you go along.
Draw a triangle and then a square to draw an envelope.
Use only the blocks you need to get to complete the level.
Colour
E
trans-unit.note: An abbreviation of the direction East

trans-unit.source: See if you can figure out how to use "draw a square" and "draw a triangle" (and some other blocks) to draw a house around the lion.
Can you find a solution using 4 blocks? Try using the given function(s).
Use one of the new functions to help me remove all of the piles on the ground with as few blocks as possible.
while path ahead

trans-unit.source: Use the new functions, "fill 8" and "remove 8", to help me level out the pile and fill in the hole.
You used extra colors. Nice!
Turtle 2

trans-unit.source: See generated JavaScript code.
trans-unit.note: tooltip (pop-up help) for button; pressing the button causes a program in the JavaScript computer language to be displayed, based on the program created by the user.

trans-unit.source: Turns me left or right by 90 degrees.

trans-unit.source: Could not load your saved file. Perhaps it was created with a different version of Blockly?
trans-unit.note: alert - There was a problem loading a file previously saved by the user. The most likely reason for the problem is that it was created with an earlier, incompatible version of Blockly. This message will be followed by technical information useful to engineers trying to understand the problem.

trans-unit.source: Procedures
trans-unit.note: category - Blocks related to [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subroutine defining or using procedures/functions].

trans-unit.source: Figure out what number to replace the question marks with to draw a circle.
See generated JavaScript code.
trans-unit.note: tooltip (pop-up help) for button; pressing the button causes a program in the JavaScript computer language to be displayed, based on the program created by the user.

trans-unit.source: Watch the video below and learn how to use blocks to make me move.
trans-unit.note: instructions - introduction to the Maze tutorial.

trans-unit.source: The condition when the bird has not gotten the food.
trans-unit.note: tooltip - 'hungry' means the bird has not gotten its food.

trans-unit.source: A repeat block repeats the blocks inside it until I reach the red marker.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'block' refers to a child's stackable toys. A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over. The red marker is the goal to be reached in the maze.

trans-unit.source: Make a square using only 3 blocks. (Remember that blocks to set color are free.)
do
trans-unit.note: verb - imperative or infinitive preceding one or more commands to a person.

trans-unit.source: move forward
trans-unit.note: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person moving (walking) in the direction he/she is facing.

trans-unit.source: If there is a path in the specified direction, then do some actions.
trans-unit.note: tooltip (pop-up help) - 'path' refers to a path through a maze.

trans-unit.source: Use the new function block called "fill 5" to help me fill in this hole.
turn left by
turn left
trans-unit.note: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person turning his head and body one quarter rotation counter-clockwise. Prefer a translation that has text in common with the translation of 'turn right'. See [[Translating:Blockly#Drop-Down_Menus]].

trans-unit.source: Here is an 'if' block: I will turn in a particular direction if there is a path in that direction. For example if there is a path to the left, I will turn left.
trans-unit.note: instructions - An example of an 'if' block is if there is a path to the left, turn left.

trans-unit.source: Use the 'if-else' block to help me get out of the maze!
trans-unit.note: instructions - an example of an 'if-else' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left, else or otherwise turn right'.

trans-unit.source: If there is a path in the specified direction, then do the first block of actions. Otherwise, do the second block of actions.
trans-unit.note: tooltip (pop-up help) - 'path' refers to a path through a maze.

trans-unit.source: Run Program
trans-unit.note: button label - Pressing the button runs the computer program the user has written.

trans-unit.source: Blocks used: %1
Share your blocks with this link:\n\n%1
trans-unit.note: alert - After the user has pressed a button to save his/her program, this provides the URL (%1) to retrieve the program. The characters '\n\n' indicate that a blank line will be displayed before the URL (in English). Leave those in unless you move %1 to the beginning or middle of the text, in which case you should use your judgment about where blank lines would be most useful.

trans-unit.source: Hints:
A program is a sequence of statements. Stack a couple of 'move forward' blocks together to help me reach the goal.
trans-unit.note: instructions - the word 'program' refers to a computer program, and the words for 'stack' and 'blocks' should be the same as for stacking children's blocks. Use the imperative verb form appropriate for speaking to a child, gender unspecified. If no gender-neutral singular/familiar form exists but a gender-neutral plural/formal form exists, use that instead.

trans-unit.source: Run the program defined by the blocks in the workspace.
trans-unit.note: tooltip - Pressing this button runs the computer program the user has written.

trans-unit.source: Draw a square, making each side a different color.
N
trans-unit.note: An abbreviation of the direction North

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.note: Yes indicates that this option is correct.

trans-unit.source: There was a problem with the request.
trans-unit.note: alert - The URL is invalid or a server error occurred. This message will be followed by technical information useful to engineers trying to understand the problem.

trans-unit.source: We can place 'if' blocks inside 'repeat' blocks. Where am I when this program ends? Click on the correct picture below.
trans-unit.note: instructions - An example of an 'if' block is if there is a path to the left, turn left. A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over. 'program' refers to a series of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.

trans-unit.source: You have %1 blocks left.
trans-unit.note: warning - Only %1 more blocks may be used, where %1 is an integer greater than 1. Do not alter the portions between pointy brackets (< and >), although you may move them within the phrase.

trans-unit.source: Draw three snowmen 150 dots tall in different colors, 100 dots apart. Use the new "draw a snowman" function and "jump forward" block.
Reset
trans-unit.note: button label - Pressing the button causes the output of the program to be erased but does not delete the user's program).

trans-unit.source: No - Try tracking my direction while following the program.
trans-unit.note: Tracking is suggesting to the user that they should follow each instruction and follow how that will affect the movement. A 'program' is a set of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.

trans-unit.source: Blockly
trans-unit.note: The project name. If readers of your language would know approximately how to pronounce 'Blockly', leave unchanged. Otherwise, include a transliteration in parentheses, such as the Russian: 'Blockly (o)'.

trans-unit.source: Hint:
trans-unit.note: title - this indicates to the user that what follows are ways to improve and/or fix their code.

trans-unit.source: turn right by
Congratulations! You have completed this level.
trans-unit.note: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the level, inviting them to precede to the next level of difficulty.

trans-unit.source: Make me remove the 4 piles.
Conditionals
An 'if' condition will do something only if the condition is true. Try turning right if there is a path to the right.
trans-unit.note: instructions - an example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.

trans-unit.source: x and y mark the bird's position. When x = 0 the bird is near the left edge, when x = 100 it's near the right edge. When y = 0 the bird is at the bottom, when y = 100 it's at the top.
trans-unit.note: tooltip - (x, y) marks the coordinate of bird, (0, 0) is the bottom left corner and (100, 100) top right.

trans-unit.source: You have0 blocks left.
trans-unit.note: warning - No more blocks may be added until some are removed. Do not alter the portions between pointy brackets (< and >), although you may move them within the phrase and replace 0 with one or more words.

trans-unit.source: Turns the turtle left or right by the specified number of degrees.
I will have to turn left when I cannot go straight. Use an 'if' block to see if their is a path in another direction.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'turn left' refers to rotating in place a quarter circle counter-clockwise. An example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations! You have solved the final level.
trans-unit.note: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the most difficult level.

trans-unit.source: list
trans-unit.note: variable name - Default [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/Variables variable] representing a [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/Lists list]. This should be a single word, preferably short.

trans-unit.source: Move me across the field, and use the functions to help me remove all the piles and fill all the holes.
That's right!
trans-unit.note: Congratulating the user on correctly answering the question.

trans-unit.source: Now change the code to draw 36 squares, each 10 degrees apart.
Try to reach the end of this path using the new repeat block.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.

trans-unit.source: Try oneo r more of the blocks below to solve this level.
Moves the turtle forward without leaving any marks.
Try to reach the end of this path using only two blocks.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.

trans-unit.source: Make me remove all the piles, using as few blocks as possible.
Try one or more of the blocks below to solve this level.
Your picture is the wrong color. For this level, it needs to be %1.
There is a solution using only 3 blocks. Can you find it?za
No
trans-unit.note: No indicates that this option is incorrect.

trans-unit.source: Continue
trans-unit.note: button - Closes the dialog and continues to the next level

trans-unit.source: turn left
trans-unit.note: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person turning his head and body one quarter rotation counter-clockwise. Prefer a translation that has text in common with the translation of 'turn right'. See [[Translating:Blockly#Drop-Down_Menus]].

trans-unit.source: Lists
Could you use fewer blocks? Try defining your own function and using it inside one of the loop block.
Try to reach the end of this path using only three blocks.
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.

trans-unit.source: length
set width
Move me forward one space.
trans-unit.note: tooltip (pop-up help) - Pegman is the humanoid icon used in Google Maps. See picture at http://goo.gl/9I64i (http://maps.google.com/intl/en/help/maps/streetview/learn/pegman.html). The term 'space' refers to a single square within a maze.

trans-unit.source: Reset
trans-unit.note: button label - Pressing the button causes Pegman return to the start of the maze (but does not delete the user's program.)

trans-unit.source: else
trans-unit.note: block text - Conjunction meaning 'otherwise', introducing commands to be performed if a previous condition was not true, as in 'if x>3, do this, else do that'. See [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/IfElse#If-Else_blocks].

trans-unit.source: Can you find a solution using 4 blocks? Try including an if block.
You have %1 blocks left.
trans-unit.note: warning - Only %1 more blocks may be used, where %1 is an integer greater than 1. Do not alter the portions between pointy brackets (< and >), although you may move them within the phrase.

trans-unit.source: Make me remove all the piles of dirt, using as few blocks as possible. Check out the new option in the dropdown menu on the while block.
Try again
trans-unit.note: button - Closes the dialog and stays on the current level

trans-unit.source: Draw anything you want. Some ideas are a stick figure, snowflake, or spiral. You could also try out the new "set width" block. Have fun!
You need to set a color other than black for this level.
What should I do to follow the path?
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'steps' refers to instructions in a computer program; 'path' refers to the path through a maze. See previous description for tense.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations! You have completed this level.
trans-unit.note: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the maze, inviting them to precede to the next level of difficulty.

trans-unit.source: After trying out these blocks, see what happens if you make them repeat 8 times. It should look a little different every time you run it.
if path to the right
trans-unit.note: condensed form of 'if there is a path to the right', as in: 'if path to the right, turn right'.

trans-unit.source: Math
Loops
Math
Functions
Could you use two while blocks to complete this level with fewer total blocks?
trans-unit.note: hint - A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over. The red marker is the goal to be reached in the maze.

trans-unit.source: set color
show turtle
Cancel
trans-unit.note: Label on button for user to press when not wanting to proceed.\n{lb}{lb}Identical|Cancel{rb}{rb}

trans-unit.source: You need to complete level 7 before doing this level.
You need to complete levels 7 and 8 before doing this level.
Move me to the hole and fill it with two shovelfuls of dirt.
CS First
trans-unit.note: The project name. 'CS' is an abbreviation for Computer Science. 'First' refers to the project's goal of introducing students to programming as early as possible in their life.

trans-unit.source: S
trans-unit.note: An abbreviation of the direction North

trans-unit.source: Run
Here are all of the blocks from the previous level. Modify "draw a house" so the turtle ends up at the bottom right corner of the new house. Use this modified function to house all the animals.
E
trans-unit.note: An abbreviation of the direction East

trans-unit.source: Can you find a solution using 2 blocks? Try using the given function(s) inside one of the loop blocks.
Will the blocks below move me to the red marker?
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'block' refers to a child's stackable toys. A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over. The red marker is the goal to be reached in the maze.

trans-unit.source: turn right
trans-unit.note: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person turning his head and body one quarter rotation clockwise. Prefer a translation that has text in common with the translation of 'turn left'. See [[Translating:Blockly#Drop-Down_Menus]].

trans-unit.source: Makes the turtle (green circle and arrow) visible or invisible.
What should I do to follow the path?
trans-unit.note: instructions - 'steps' refers to instructions in a computer program; 'path' refers to the path through a maze. See previous description for tense.

trans-unit.source: OK
else
trans-unit.note: conjunction - 'otherwise', introducing commands to be performed if a previous condition was not true, as in 'if x>3, do this, else do that'.

trans-unit.source: a visual programming environment
You can use more than one 'if' statement.
trans-unit.note: instructions - an example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.

trans-unit.source: Turtle 3
trans-unit.note: brief title - Specifies that this is Blockly's '''Turtle 3''' tutorial.
